Amanita (agaric mushrooms).Note: Responsible for 95% of fatalities from mushroom poisoning, the death cap mushroom being foremost.

Arsenic.Note: Arsenic poisoning was difficult to determine (hence its popularity as a tool for murder) until 1836, when the Marsh Test was invented.

Belladonna (deadly nightshade).Note: One of the most toxic plants in the world; consumption of 10-20 berries by an adult will probably cause death.

Black Widow Spider Venom (latrotoxin).Note: Rarely causes death if medical treatment is provided.

Chloroform.Note: Widely used as an anesthetic in the 1800-1900s; however, a high-strength toxic dose may cause death.

Cobra Venom.Note: Contact with eyes will cause immediate irritation and, if untreated, blindness. If serum is available, then major injury and death can be avoided.

Curare.Note: Common name for poison administered to arrows in South America. Harmless if ingested—only direct application via a skin wound results in paralysis.

Cyanide.Note: Highly toxic—causes death if ingested as cyanide salt or inhaled through gas.

Rattlesnake Venom.Note: Venom destroys tissue, causing necrosis, although rarely fatal (especially if an antidote is given within 1 to 2 hours).

Rohypnol.Note: Odorless, colorless, and only available in modern game settings.

Strychnine.Note: Death within hours if medical treatment is not provided.

Yew.Note: One of the most toxic plants in the world; consumption of 1-2 handfulls of needles by an adult will probably cause death.
